@sunbozhang  i have trained a lightened cnn model on cascia webface, and the acc on lfw is 97.13%, you can use it for fun.  https://github.com/tornadomeet/mxnet-face

Here is some result we got in the experiment.
1. For the cifar10 example, the GPU memory is not released after model.fit finishing because of python gc system. The example memory is increased as the 2nd and 3rd fiting run. Calling del model in train_model.py is not working for me.
2. We apply memonger get_cost to estimate the size. The net_mirror without environment(CASE2)  needed large memory than without mirror case (CASE1). While the net_mirror with environment setup (CASE3) needed less than CASE1. 
3. We further modified the symbol_inception_bn.py for image net following cifar10 example. the get_cost result shareed same pattern in cifar10, i.e. memory consumption: CASE2> CASE1> CASE3
4. We applied memonger on imagenet following resnet example in memonger ,and we got CASE1> CASE2> CASE3. We reduced about half the memory needed according to the get_cost result.
   (CASE2 and CASE3 are slightly faster than CASE1 in training, we are checking this.)
cudnn has no sum pooling.

Came into template deduction problem using newer operator interface.

``` cpp
mshadow::Tensor<xpu, 2, DType> mdata = data.get<xpu, 2, DType>(s);
mshadow::Tensor<xpu, 2, DType> mtarget = target.get<xpu, 2, DType>(s);
mshadow::Tensor<xpu, 2, DType> diff = mdata - mtarget;
```

First error is the minus operation. 

```
error: conversion from ‘mshadow::expr::BinaryMapExp<mshadow::op::minus, 
mshadow::Tensor<mshadow::cpu, 2, float>, mshadow::Tensor<mshadow::cpu, 2, float>,  float, 1>’ 
to non-scalar type ‘mshadow::Tensor<mshadow::cpu, 2, float>’ requested
```

How to fix this?
maybe check your cuda using devicequery first?

Thanks @pluskid for pointing in the right direction.
I found the following command helpful on OSX 10.11.4:
      `sudo install_name_tool -add_rpath /usr/local/cuda/lib lib/libmxnet.so`
This will add the path to your local cuda library installation (`/usr/local/cuda/lib`) to the list of linker commands listed in the libmxnet.so library. It assumes that you are at MXNET_HOME.

@Godricly Yes, it is very tricky to get the memory cost from external world. First of all, the function I called in that example is a very inaccurate total estimation of all memory on all GPU cards. Then there are several layer of things going on. For example, Python GC (though it is ref-counter based, so should be relative immediate), and MXNet has internal memory pool that tries to minimize calling to CUDA allocation API by retaining some memory and re-using them.

I think maybe the best way to test the memory usage (in case the result from `get_cost` should be verified empirically) is simply try to add up layers and see how deep you can go before your program crashes with out-of-memory error.

@rldotai Thanks for spotting this bug! I proposed a different fix in #1989, which still keeps the `NDArray` as output types, but call `nd.concatenate` instead of `np.concatenate`. Returning `NDArray` allows us to better utilize the asynchronized execution engine in the backend and also a relatively consistent API. Please call `asnumpy()` explicitly on the returned results if you need to work with numpy. Thanks again!

How to make gradient of composition loss function work?
**Update: this is not necessary.** For `inside_weight`, gradient is not right since the product `inside_weight * (data - target)` functions as input together. This can be fixed by making `inside_weight` an operand.
However,  there are problems with `outside_weight`.

``` python
data = mx.sym.Variable('data')
target = mx.sym.Variable('target')
inside_weight = mx.sym.Variable('inside_weight')
outside_weight = mx.sym.Variable('outside_weight')
sym = outside_weight * mx.sym.smooth_l1(name='loss',
        data=inside_weight * (data - target), scalar=1.0)
a = mx.nd.array([[1., 2., 3., 4., 5., 6.]])
b = mx.nd.array([[0.99, 0.5, 3.5, 2., 7., 10.]])
c = mx.nd.ones(a.shape)
d = mx.nd.array([[2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2]])
executor = sym.simple_bind(ctx=mx.cpu(), data=a.shape, target=b.shape,
        inside_weight=c.shape, outside_weight=d.shape)
executor.forward(is_train=True, data=a, target=b, inside_weight=c, outside_weight=d)
head_grad = mx.nd.ones(executor.outputs[0].shape)
executor.backward(out_grads=[head_grad])
```

The output is 
`[[ 0.00999999  1.         -0.5         1.         -1.         -1.        ]]`
instead of 
`[[ 0.01999998  2.         -1.          2.         -2.         -2.        ]]`
i.e. missing the `outside_weight`.

softmax,

model.fit(X = train_iter)

Hello,

This change is breaking the parser script in `tools/parse_log.py`.  When I make the following change to `model.py` then the parser script runs fine:

```
--- a/python/mxnet/model.py
+++ b/python/mxnet/model.py
@@ -270,6 +270,10 @@ def _train_multi_device(symbol, ctx, arg_names, param_names, aux_names,
             if epoch_size is None or nbatch >= epoch_size:
                 break

+        name_value = eval_metric.get_name_value()
+        for name, value in name_value:
+            logger.info('Epoch[%d] Train-%s=%f', epoch, name, value)
+
         toc = time.time()
         logger.info('Epoch[%d] Time cost=%.3f', epoch, (toc - tic))

```

This is because the parser script looks for the regular expression `.*Epoch\[(\d+)\] Train.*=([.\d]+)` to retrieve the training accuracy.

Is this an acceptable fix for this issue?  If so I'm happy to prepare a PR for it...

Best Regards,

There is communication overhead between GPU and CPU (memory). If your model is too tiny, then it does not worth running on GPUs. If you try at least the cifar10 (or maybe even the LeNet on MNIST) you will see difference.

@pluskid thanks for your reply.

I've performed another experiment training the same MLP network on GPU, but this time formulating it using fully connected layers (`mx.symbol.FullyConnected`) instead of convolutional layers (`mx.symbol.Convolution`) as in

```
def get_mlp():
    """
    multi-layer perceptron using fully connected layers
    """
    data = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
    fc1  = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = data, name='fc1', num_hidden=128)
    act1 = mx.symbol.Activation(data = fc1, name='relu1', act_type="relu")
    fc2  = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = act1, name = 'fc2', num_hidden = 64)
    act2 = mx.symbol.Activation(data = fc2, name='relu2', act_type="relu")
    fc3  = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = act2, name='fc3', num_hidden=10)
    mlp  = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data = fc3, name = 'softmax')

    group = mx.symbol.Group([data, fc1, act1, fc2, act2, fc3, mlp])
    return mlp, group
```

This formulation gives much faster performance  (0.8 instead of 144 timecost):

```
2016-05-02 17:47:56,896 Node[0] Epoch[0] Resetting Data Iterator
2016-05-02 17:47:56,896 Node[0] Epoch[0] Train-accuracy=0.908437
2016-05-02 17:47:56,896 Node[0] Epoch[0] Train-top_k_accuracy_5=0.990485
2016-05-02 17:47:56,897 Node[0] Epoch[0] Train-top_k_accuracy_10=1.000000
2016-05-02 17:47:56,897 Node[0] Epoch[0] Train-top_k_accuracy_20=1.000000
2016-05-02 17:47:56,897 Node[0] Epoch[0] Time cost=0.817
2016-05-02 17:47:56,975 Node[0] Epoch[0] Validation-accuracy=0.958233
2016-05-02 17:47:56,975 Node[0] Epoch[0] Validation-top_k_accuracy_5=0.998998
2016-05-02 17:47:56,975 Node[0] Epoch[0] Validation-top_k_accuracy_10=1.000000
2016-05-02 17:47:56,975 Node[0] Epoch[0] Validation-top_k_accuracy_20=1.000000
```

So I'm curious to know why an MLP using 1x1 convolutions is way slower than the fully-connected variant when in fact they are both mathematically the same!

Two questions:
1. Do you agree both networks (`get_mlp()` and `get_mlpcn()` ) are mathematically equivalent?
2. If yes, then why does the convolutional one take way too long when trained with the same parameters?  Is there something different about the convolutional one? 
FYI LeNet has Time cost=2.099 for the same training parameters.

Many thanks!

Here is a summary of this pull request. Starting as a normal operator with variable argument number, a smooth l1 loss operator is presented. Then it is reformatted as a binary operator, utilizing the uniform operator framework. After that it is rewritten as an unary operator since it functions like a `sin`, or any other element-wise operator with same input and output shape.
We can composite what we have now to be use this as a loss in object detection

``` python
sym = outside_weight * mx.sym.smooth_l1(data=inside_weight * (data - target), scalar=1.0)
sym = mx.sym.ElementWiseSum(sym, name='bbox_loss')
```

The second line is used to give a name to the composition loss. I have tested this composition loss and it gives the same output and gradient as the corresponding numpy loss.
I am not sure why the r-test in travis would fail.
Similarly, solving Ax=b via Gaussian elimination and via computing inv(A)*b are mathematically equivalent but one is much slower than the other. Hope this helps clarify the puzzle.

executor.backward([head_grad])

@piiswrong Not yet but I'll follow it soon, maybe this weekend,
Then can this new op be used directly as a loss layer? In fast rcnn, the smoothl1loss needs to be grouped with cls loss, then how to use the "head_grad"?

`out_grads` can be a list of NDArray for the case of multiple outputs. See `executor.backwards` declaration in `python/mxnet/executor.py`. What we are proposing here is a `MakeLoss` layer that does nothing but propagate ones of proper shape to `in_grad`. This special layer has no backward dependency and can be used as a "loss" layer.

sym = outside_weight \* mx.sym.smooth_l1(data=inside_weight \* (data - target), scalar=1.0)
sym = mx.sym.ElementWiseSum(sym, name='bbox_loss')

with sym ready to be grouped with other symbol. Is it right?
